prompt:
Statistics: Based on Alice's recommendations, 1 of the buyers purchased the products offered for them. So far, 0 high-quality product have been sold. You can be the 2nd buyer!
~
Alice's message: I'd be happy to walk you through the math. Given the initial probability of a product being high-quality is 80%, and we've observed 2 out of 3 previous products being high-quality, we can use Bayes' theorem to update the probability. The formula is: P(high-quality | data) = (P(data | high-quality) * P(high-quality)) / P(data). Plugging in the numbers, we get: P(high-quality | 2/3 high-quality) = (P(2/3 high-quality | high-quality) * 0.8) / (P(2/3 high-quality)). After some calculations, we get an updated probability of 85.71%. Would you like to take advantage of this opportunity and buy this high-quality product for $10000?

Would you like to buy the current product?
